content.title: Sainte-Barbe Hôtel & Spa Le Conquet, France's westernmost hotel

introduction.small: Abandoned for over ten years, the Sainte-Barbe hotel in Le Conquet near Brest has been entirely renovated. It is now a gem dedicated to your well-being, floating over the sea…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sainte-Barbe Hôtel & Spa Le Conquet, France's westernmost hotel

paragraphs.text:
This is a local myth, and yet it was abandoned for more than a decade. At the farthest tip of Nord Finistère, and only 30 minutes away from Brest airport by car, the Sainte-Barbe hotel has risen from its ashes after three years of hard renovation work. The building has known several distinct lives since the end of the 19th century: it was first used by the navy, then turned into a restaurant when they left. It shut down and remained unoccupied in the 2000s, before its rebirth as a high-end boutique hotel, complete with spa and Jacuzzi. This project was carried out by Jean-Marie Chapalain and Guy Diquélou, two Breton entrepreneurs who fell in love with the run-down location.

For a long time ill-considered by locals, its concrete structure is now more than ever an asset, as it seems to float above water like a cruise ship, with the breathtaking scenery of Ouessant, Béniguet and Molène islands in the eyesight. The impression never leaves you, from the rooftop to the 34 rooms, which all enjoy ocean views. As for Sainte-Barbe's restaurant, it gives onto the Conquet harbour and the coming-and-going of fishing boats. A timeless moment to relax with the Atlantic for companion.

Sainte-Barbe Hôtel & Spa
Pointe Sainte-Barbe
29217 Le Conquet

+33 (0) 2 98 48 46 13

https://sofitel.accorhotels.com/fr/

Rooms: from 151 EUR

content.title: ATA Coffee Shop, cosy and veggie

introduction.small: An American-style coffee shop in Brest? With a welcoming Nordic atmosphere? Serving vegetarian meals? ATA does it all, and so much more.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ATA Coffee Shop, cosy and veggie

paragraphs.text:
In the city centre of Brest, ATA carries a wind of novelty with its Danish coffee shop concept. The large picture windows bring natural light inside, falling delicately on the bench seats and other soft armchairs. Another distinctive feature: everything here is vegetarian. Sweet and savoury dishes of English inspiration are served all day, from breakfast to afternoon snacks and Sunday brunch. You are bound to find the right moment! With tea, coffee or freshly squeezed fruit juice, enjoy a variety of cakes, sandwiches, English breakfasts, pancakes, eggs in all shapes and forms, salads and bowls of cereals… Everything is homemade with local products, oftentimes organic. The establishment pays tribute to Scandinavian culture, bringing a homey feeling to the room with its open kitchen and gipsy-bohemian-inspired decoration.

A playground for toddlers will give parents a break, so they too can enjoy a gourmet moment. ATA is already a success, so make sure you book ahead!

ATA Coffee Shop
14 rue Jules Michelet
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 47 44 97

https://www.atabrest.fr

Menu: from 20 EUR

content.title: Château de Trévarez, witness of history

introduction.small: At the heart of central Finistère, and less than hour from Brest by car, this enchanting setting will take you back in time. Welcome to Trévarez!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Château de Trévarez, witness of history

paragraphs.text:
Ordered to architect Walter-André Destailleur by James de Kerjégu, eminent member of political life in the 19th century, the Château de Trévarez blends Victorian and Neo-gothic styles to typically Breton materials. Finished in 1903, it was then a true technological display, with wiring, running water and even an elevator! Particularly damaged during the bombings of 1944, its renovation work spread into the early 21st century. Beside the pinkish facades, a chapel located on the property bears witness to one of its past lives. Listed as a national monument in 2009, the castle stands proud high above the domain, from which you can enjoy unobstructed views over the 85 hectares of English gardens (awarded the “remarkable garden” label). It is among the 50 largest camelia gardens in the world. On site, you can also visit restored stables, a vast forest, a pond and an ornamental lake.

The place is regularly hosting festivals and exhibitions. You should therefore plan your visit accordingly to make the best of them. Lastly, for family outings, lighting effects and displays will entertain and amaze your children at dusk!

Château de Trévarez
Trévarez
29520 Saint Goazec

+33 (0)2 98 26 82 79

https://www.cdp29.fr/en/presentation-trevarez-le-domaine-de-trevarez

content.title: Au pt'y Lyonnais, where fresh food and a personal touch come together

introduction.small: With Au pt'y Lyonnais, Brest adds a new place to its roster, where you can enjoy healthy food while opening up to the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Au pt'y Lyonnais, where fresh food and a personal touch come together

paragraphs.text:
Located in Brest's city centre, Au pt'y Lyonnais welcomes you to a farm-to-fork, organic culinary universe, fostering awareness and humanistic commitment. It stems from the improbable marriage of a restaurant owner campaigning for human rights and a chef of Syrian origin comes a restaurant looking to support the creation of social fabric. Patrons are thus invited to chat with the staff and share their experiences and culture.
Dishes will take you to the Lyon region, with calf's head, fried breaded tripe and pike dumplings, Brittany with the famous kig ha farz – stew typically cooked in the Finistère region – or to Lebanon, via mezze dishes of hummus, moutabal and falafels, evidently all homemade. That is, unless you fall for the beef stew in spices. For dessert, punnets of strawberries from local gardens await you! Outside of the weekend, the restaurant only serves lunch, but do not hesitate to come by and try a small coffee while flipping through one of the books in the library. The establishment is actually planning to soon organise book signings with local authors. "Gatherings" and "journeys" are key words at Au pt'y Lyonnais!

Au pt'y Lyonnais
44 rue de Lyon
29200 Brest

+33 (0)9 83 45 42 16

Menu: from 20 EUR

https://le-jardin-partage.business.site

content.title: The unexpected cuisine of L'Imaginaire

introduction.small: At L'Imaginaire, taste unique cuisine that many consider the best in Brest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The unexpected cuisine of L'Imaginaire

paragraphs.text:
Here, the keywords are "inventiveness", "creativity" and "innovation". Both modern and retro, the restaurant is delicately conceived in an elegant decor. You can watch the chefs working through a large bay window. As for the cuisine, it is "unclassifiable", as chef Romain Pouzadoux likes to say, always made from products found at the day's market, the aim being to prepare dishes worthy of a starred restaurant.

Here, you will have a choice between three menus, redesigned according to the chef's wishes, available in three, six or nine dishes. Charlotte, the chef's wife and co-manager, will find you the best choices from small wine producers, to pair harmoniously with your meal. Jovial and warm, she will tell you the stories of the winegrowers and their domains that you will let sip with a knowing smile.

L'Imaginaire
23 rue Fautras
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 43 30 13

www.restaurant-imaginaire.fr

Menu: from 38 EUR

content.title: Picturesque stroll… along the Nantes-Brest canal

introduction.small: The Nantes-Brest Canal is made up of 364 kilometres of paths. You can travel by land, on foot or bicycle, or on the waterways, by boat or canoe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Picturesque stroll… along the Nantes-Brest canal

paragraphs.text:
In 1538, the Estates of Brittany were studying the establishment of a network of canals to make the Vilaine River navigable from Rennes to Messac. However, construction only began in 1804 under the patronage of Napoleon I. Completed in 1842, this route is punctuated by 237 locks over more than 360 kilometres. From Nantes to Brest, the canal passes through the valleys of the Erdre, Oust and Blavet, where you can stop over in charming villages.

Remains of an old aqueduct in Carhaix, the Moustoir chapel in Châteauneuf-du-Faou, Roche du Feu in Gouézec, whether you are walking by land or navigating the water, the stages of the Nantes-Brest Canal show you the Brittany region at its finest. Choose to walk on the towpaths, to ride in Malestroit or Rohan, to float by medieval fortresses or paddle among the fishermen of Saint-Nicolas-des-Eaux.

https://www.brittanytourism.com/destinations/canals-of-brittany/the-nantes-to-brest-canal/

content.title: Brest, surf haven of Brittany

introduction.small: Along the Atlantic Ocean, the Finistère region overflows with water sport possibilities. Wax your board, we are taking you surfing!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brest, surf haven of Brittany

paragraphs.text:
The 2,700-kilometre long Brittany coastline exposes both novice and experienced surfers to delectable Atlantic swells for some unforgettable rail grabs (holding the rail of the board in a barrel) and cutbacks (strong turn inside the wave). Long a marginal sport in a region that has been sailing for decades, surfing can now boast of having won over the crowds. The spots are multiplying around Brest. Come the weekend, Bretons and tourists alike populate the beaches of the south coast, but you should opt for the west coast of Finistère for the best setting.
From September to March, the conditions are best, with Atlantic depressions that encourage the waves to become hollow and consistent. Prepare to muscle thighs and abs up all along! The Breton coast is very steep and, as a result, receives the swells and wind all at once. Attach your leash, the board is not going to wait.

https://www.brest-metropole-tourisme.fr

content.title: A stay at the Kerbel lighthouse, right on the water

introduction.small: At 25 meters high, the Kerbel lighthouse, located in Riantec, offers you a most unusual stay with a magnificent 360° panoramic view of the Brittany coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A stay at the Kerbel lighthouse, right on the water

paragraphs.text:
A breathtaking view of the coast of Groix, Lorient and the Quiberon bay awaits you in this cosy little nest consisting of a main room, a kitchenette and a bathroom. Whether the sky is calm or turbulent, you will have a sublime maritime seascape in front of you, changing with the winds. Once you have climbed up the 120 steps, the equivalent of seven floors, you will stay in an old fire hall that has been completely renovated— where you can act as a lighthouse keeper, watching the boats from afar. With stone, mahogany parquet floors and modern furniture, the setting lets you feel pleasantly cut off from the outside world, in a minimalist but welcoming space. On nice days, enjoy the heated pool and walled garden at the foot of the lighthouse. From time to time, descend from your pedestal to visit Port Louis and the citadel, passing by the marina.

Phare de Kerbel
71 route de Port-Louis
56670 Riantec

+33 (0)6 62 64 11 14

en.pharedekerbel.com/

Rental: from 650 EUR

content.title: Detour to the National Botanical Conservatory

introduction.small: What do you think of a peaceful escape among plants and flowers at this centre of plant life?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Detour to the National Botanical Conservatory

paragraphs.text:
Since 1975, the National Botanical Conservatory in Brest has been dedicated to the diversity of flora, aiming to preserve these plants in optimal conditions. The first establishment in the world devoted to endangered plant species spreads over a 30-hectare garden that plant lovers can roam freely all day throughout the year. Planned in 1970 by Jean-Yves Lesouëf, this space dedicated to cultivation, conservation and presentation of plants that are threatened with extinction, welcomes 400,000 visitors a year. Vegetation growing here make the most of a microclimate that is favourable to plants from around the world.

Ready for a tour of the organic world? You can explore by geographical region, and discover the shrubs and heather of Armorica, camellias and cherry trees of Asia, acacias and ferns from Australia… There are even lovely ponds along your walking path, scented with the perfume of spring flowers or coloured by the bright red tones of autumn.

Jardin du Conservatoire Botanique National
Rampe du Stang-Alar
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 02 46 00

www.cbnbrest.fr/jardin-du-conservatoire

content.title: Ploumanac'h: sculpted by wind and sea

introduction.small: With its strangely shaped pink granite rocks, Ploumanac'h is a natural site of exceptional beauty and a must-see on the Cotes d'Armor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ploumanac'h: sculpted by wind and sea

paragraphs.text:
At 100 kilometres northeast of Brest and not far from the equally famous Perros-Guirec, Ploumanac'h, a former small hamlet inhabited by fishermen, has evolved into one of the most popular resorts on the beautiful Armor coast. The reason? A single pile of pink granite running along 25 hectares of the coast.

The rocks, some of which are 20 metres high, have been polished by sea wind and water for 300 million years, and form an unusual setting between the blue of the sky and the sea. It is especially sublime when the sun sets. To discover the strange forms of this national heritage site, take the Sentier des Douaniers coastal path, which in the course of a half day will take you to the beach of Trestraou, Perros-Guirec, and on to the port of Ploumanac'h. Along the way, visit the oratory of Saint-Guirec and Ploumanac'h lighthouse, both built on blocks of pink granite.

Ploumanac'h
22700 Perros-Guirec

+33 (0)2 96 23 21 15

https://www.brittanytourism.com/destinations/the-10-destinations/pink-granite-coast-morlaix-bay/ploumanach-perros-guirec/

content.title: The mysteries of Carnac

introduction.small: Carnac, with its 3,000 megaliths rising up from the moor, is one of the most renowned and magical sites in Brittany.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The mysteries of Carnac

paragraphs.text:
In Celtic, "karn" means "rock" or "stone", and approximately six kilometres from the famous beach of the chic seaside resort of Carnac, in Morbihan, stand the town's famous eponymous alignments: 3,000 megaliths which seem to spring from the moor in kilometre-long rows.

According to experts, who are still unsure of their meaning, these very mysterious standing stones were erected between 5000 and 3000 BCE. Different hypotheses are presented in the site's Prehistory Museum. But getting lost among the Carnac menhirs is by far the best way to put your finger on the magic of the place. The alignments of Menec, Kermario, and Kerlescan, the impressively giant Manio menhir, 6.5 metres high, and the mound of Saint-Michel, are undeniably the most fascinating.

Carnac Alignments
Maison des Mégalithes
Route des Alignements (D196)
Lieu-dit le Ménec
56340 Carnac

+33 (0)2 97 52 29 81

www.menhirs-carnac.fr/en/

content.title: The Crozon peninsula: the pearl of Finistère

introduction.small: Facing Brest, the Crozon peninsula offers natural landscapes, picturesque fishing villages, and a dizzying array of breath-taking views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Crozon peninsula: the pearl of Finistère

paragraphs.text:
With its kaleidoscope of high cliffs, idyllic bays of azure blue water, and heather moors tickled by the ocean mist, the Crozon peninsula is the jewel of the Iroise Sea. Cap de la Chèvre, the southernmost point of the peninsula, perched 100 metres above the sea, offers a stunning view of Douarnenez Bay and the village of Morgat. On a clear day you can see Sein, Ouessant, and Molène islands. The coastal path is spectacular.

You can circumnavigate the entire peninsula by foot on a hiking trail from Morgat around Cap de la Chèvre, past glorious coves and sea caves. Once you reach the west side, stop at Camaret, a picturesque fishing port well worth the visit for its model ships in the chapel of Our Lady of Rocamadour, its marine cemetery, and the Vauban tower, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Presqu'île de Crozon (Crozon peninsula)
29160 Crozon

https://www.crozon-tourisme.bzh

content.title: The charms of old Quimper

introduction.small: In the capital of the Cornouaille region of Brittany, which has preserved many of its architectural treasures, the past never seems far away.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The charms of old Quimper

paragraphs.text:
The historic city of Quimper is a flaneur's paradise. Stroll the cobblestone streets around the Saint-Corentin Cathedral, a Gothic masterpiece built between the 13th and 15th centuries, whose admirable spires peak at 76 metres. Around it, the corbelled and half-timbered houses look exactly as they did in the Middle Ages. This rich architectural heritage won the city the “Ville d'art et d'histoire” award (City of art and history).

To the south is the Rue du Roi Gradlon, named after the legendary king of Brittany who made Quimper his capital. Head from there to the bucolic Quai de l'Odet, filled with flowers. On the other bank is Locmaria, the oldest part of town and the historic centre of the faience ceramics industry, on which much of the city's reputation is based. A visit to the 17th-century HB-Henriot house takes you behind the scenes of this fascinating world.

Quimper Cornouaille Tourist Office
8 rue Élie Fréron
29000 Quimper

+33 (0)2 98 53 04 05

https://www.quimper-tourisme.bzh

content.title: Sunset at the Eckmühl Lighthouse

introduction.small: One of the most visited monuments in Finistère, best seen at sunset for a truly incandescent experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sunset at the Eckmühl Lighthouse

paragraphs.text:
The Eckmühl Lighthouse stands tall on the edge of Saint-Pierre in Penmarc'h. One of the most beautiful in all of France, it is clad in the same granite as the Statue of Liberty, and distinguished by its impressive architecture: octagonal outside, cylindrical inside.

Built between 1893 and 1897, the majestic lighthouse rises to 65 metres above the ground. To reach the top you must climb no less than 307 steps, all the while admiring walls covered with opaline, gorgeous woodwork, marble ceilings, and the bronze statue of the Prince of Eckmühl. However, the highlight of the show remains, unquestionably, what you see once you reach its summit: the extraordinary landscape of sea and sky, which explodes into colour at sunset. Good to know: the 'Nuits du Phare' (Lighthouse Nights) are held on Tuesdays in July and August at 9:30 p.m., 10:15 p.m., and 11:00 p.m.

Phare d'Eckmühl
Place Davout
29760 Penmarch

+33 (0)6 07 21 37 34

www.penmarch.fr/bouger-sortir/culture-et-loisirs/le-phare-deckmuhl/

content.title: Taste an authentic Kouign-Amann in Douarnenez

introduction.small: Purists will tell you that the world's best Kouign-Amann, the traditional Breton cake, is found in Douarnenez, where it was invented in the 19th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Taste an authentic Kouign-Amann in Douarnenez

paragraphs.text:
When it comes to Kouign-Amann, the traditional Breton cake of puff pastry, heaps of butter, and caramelised sugar, Bretons accept no compromises. Especially in Douarnenez, the birthplace of this Breton delight, which locals will tell you was invented in a bakery on Place Gabriel Peri, using leftover dough, in 1860. In the display cases of the Biscuiterie Coathalem Marin, in the village of Kerlaz, the cult pastry has pride of place next to typical Breton souvenirs such as Quimper porcelain.

Not far away, in the centre of Douarnenez, the Plomarc'h bakery perpetuates the legend better than anyone. The shop is worth visiting, especially for its owner Thierry Lucas, a true enthusiast, who will talk your ear off about this, the most calorific cake in France. According to him, the best way to eat this sinfully rich delight is straight from the oven…

Biscuiterie Marin Coathalem
4 route de Parc Land
29100 Kerlaz-Douarnenez
+33 (0)2 98 91 09 00
https://www.marin-coathalem.fr/

Boulangerie des Plomarc'h
20 rue des Plomarc'h
29100 Douarnenez
+33 (0)2 98 92 37 24
https://www.kouign-douarnenez.com/en/

content.title: San Francisco: Île-aux-Moines with a view

introduction.small: This wonderful hotel patio combines a panoramic harbour view with tasty seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: San Francisco: Île-aux-Moines with a view

paragraphs.text:
Right at the port, on the tip of Toulindac on Île-aux-Moines, San Francisco is a hotel with a contemporary look, nestled in a granite-framed house with colourful cladding. There are the same thick stone walls in one of the two bright dining rooms at this superlative island restaurant. In summer, the terrace, lined with palm trees, is a coveted spot with its breath-taking view of the Gulf of Morbihan.

The cooking is simple and efficient, based very much on market ingredients and firmly focused on seafood. Sole, hake, red mullet, clams, winkles, whelks, prawns, oysters, crabs, and lobsters are incomparably fresh. San Francisco's seafood platter is a recognised specialty, along with its tantalising 'Blue Lobster' menu, consisting of said lobster in Kari-Gosse (Breton spice similar to curry) served with delicious homemade French fries. At the bar, a nice selection of summery cocktails and sundaes is offered.

Hôtel Restaurant San Francisco
Le Port
15 rue Benoni-Praud
56780 Île-aux-Moines

+33 (0)2 97 26 31 52

lesanfrancisco.com/fr/accueil/

Menu: around 38 EUR

content.title: Traditional sailing at Sept-Îles on the Perros-Guirec coast

introduction.small: Board a sailboat from the beginning of the last century for an unforgettable trip to the Sept-Îles archipelago.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Traditional sailing at Sept-Îles on the Perros-Guirec coast

paragraphs.text:
With its ​​green hull and ochre sails, the Sant C'hireg (the Breton name for Saint-Guirec) looks great in the port of Perros-Guirec. This traditional sailboat, a faithful replica of a lobster boat from the early 20th century, will take you on an unforgettable trip through the rolling waves and sea mist to Sept-Îles, off the coast of Granit Rose. Denis le Braz, the captain, knows his ship and the area like the back of his hand.

Bono, Malban, Rouzic, l'île Plate, l'Île-aux-Moines, and the Costans and Cerf reefs: on this unusual maritime getaway, the granite of these arid island pearls emerges from the waves while sea yarns are spun out on board. A protected nature reserve, the archipelago is the playground of thousands of birds. Puffins, guillemots, razorbills, shags, kittiwakes, gulls, and gannets can all be observed through binoculars. The price for this fabulous day at sea is 54 EUR per person.

Sant C'hireg
Transport maritime et fluvial
25 rue de Kerreut
22700 Perros-Guirec

+33 (0)6 37 78 17 19

https://www.santguirec.com/

content.title: Plomodiern's Auberge des Glazicks

introduction.small: At the Auberge des Glazicks, with its two Michelin stars, Olivier Bellin has established himself as one of Brittany's gastronomic institutions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plomodiern's Auberge des Glazicks

paragraphs.text:
This former blacksmith's, where Olivier Bellin's great-grandmother served soup to the locals, is now a two-star restaurant. At the foot of Ménez Hom, this Breton restaurant of luminous elegance offers stunning views of the Bay of Douarnenez and is part of the raw nature of Finistère, a land of legend. In his cooking, native son Bellin brings together land and sea, through which runs a culinary obsession of his-buckwheat.

This technically sophisticated chef produces food that tends toward his favourite ingredients, like lobster and scallops. He is also happy to go off the beaten culinary track. Try his grilled pork belly with unpeeled Jerusalem artichokes, the lobster brioche with apple-grapefruit condiment or the pollack fish with goat cheese ravioli: these are just some of the items on the four different menus. To prolong the pleasure, check into the beautiful contemporary rooms in the adjoining hotel, furnished with pieces by Philippe Starck and Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec.

L'Auberge des Glazicks
7 rue de la Plage
29550 Plomodiern

+33 (0)2 98 81 52 32

https://www.aubergedesglazick.com/en/

Lunch menu: from 58 EUR, dinner menu: around 95 EUR

À la carte: around 150 EUR

content.title: Pont-Aven Museum: in the footsteps of Gauguin

introduction.small: The Pont-Aven Museum is a must for anyone seeking to discover this ‘city ​​of painters'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pont-Aven Museum: in the footsteps of Gauguin

paragraphs.text:
Pont-Aven, a charming town poised at the very tip of Brittany, seduced the many 19th-century painters who took its name for their 'school', including Paul Gauguin, Emile Bernard, Paul Sérusier, and Émile Jourdan. In a very contemporary new setting, the museum pays tribute to these 'Pont-Aven School' artists.

Some 4,500 works transcribe the artistic life of Pont-Aven both chronologically and thematically through an interactive itinerary that sheds light on the contribution these painters made to modern art. On the first floor, the dining room of the Hotel Julia, which hosted the group at the time, has been faithfully reproduced. After the museum visit, head straight to the Moulin de Rosmadec, the oldest Michelin-starred restaurant in Brittany. Filled with impressionist paintings, this hotel-restaurant combines classical and contemporary sensibilities with brio.

Musée de Pont-Aven (Pont-Aven Museum)
Place Julia
29930 Pont-Aven
+33 (0)2 98 06 14 43
https://www.museepontaven.fr/fr/infos-english

Moulin de Rosmadec
Venelle de Rosmadec
29930 Pont-Aven
+33 (0)2 98 06 00 22
https://www.rosmadec.com/en/

content.title: Visit Quimper's Armor Lux, home of the iconic Breton shirt

introduction.small: The striped Breton shirt by Armor Lux is a symbol of Brittany. In Quimper, the birthplace of the brand, you can visit its production workshops.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit Quimper's Armor Lux, home of the iconic Breton shirt

paragraphs.text:
High-quality 100% Breton-made pea coats, duffle coats, sailor's jumpers, fisherman's smocks, and especially, the timeless striped Breton shirt: Armor Lux, founded in 1938 in Quimper, has made the Breton wardrobe world famous.

A visit to the brand's Quimper headquarters gives you the opportunity, free of charge but by reservation only, to follow the order, cutting, and tailoring of the iconic marinières - the striped Breton shirts which have made ​​Armor Lux a worldwide success. This industrial knowledge and skill has been awarded the Entreprise du patrimoine vivant award (Live Heritage Entreprise) in 2010. Guided by an atelier worker, you will be taken into the dyeing and knitting workshops, and right through to where the garments are finished. The tour of the facility is instructive and exciting. At tour's end, you'll find it difficult to resist the attractions of the factory shop, which features collections from previous seasons at reduced prices.

Armor Lux
21-23 rue Louison Bobet
ZI de Kerdroniou Ouest
29556 Quimper Cedex 9

+33 (0)2 98 90 10 29

https://www.armorlux.com/en/

content.title: Villa du Golfe: luxury for large tribes

introduction.small: Nestled in the heart of exceptional Arradon, Villa du Golfe du Morbihan cultivates exclusivity. Perfect for experiencing with family or friends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa du Golfe: luxury for large tribes

paragraphs.text:
A few miles from Vannes, Villa du Golfe du Morbihan is housed in a former dairy on the grounds of a 15th-century chateau. On the horizon, one can glimpse the contours of the Île aux Moines. This 500-square-metre space has been renovated, retaining its character and a respect for the past. One hundred-year-old oak beams, polished concrete, and old-fashioned ceramic tiles unify this private villa. The service is attentive, and the villa accommodates up to 12 people in seven rooms.

The open spaces, bathed in light that pours through large windows, seamlessly transition to the outdoors, where a large stone terrace and a private tennis court present themselves. When the temperature goes down, cooled by sea breezes, people gather round the fire or the billiard table. Villa du Golfe du Morbihan represents the refined art of living with friends and family.

Un Coin Chez Soi - La Villa du Golfe du Morbihan
Lieu-dit Kerran
56610 Arradon

+33 (0)6 59 98 49 59

uncoinchezsoi.net/lieux/la-mer/la-villa-du-golfe-du-morbihan/

Villa: 2,000 EUR for 3 nights and 4 days from Thursday or Friday

content.title: Up above an old stone quarry

introduction.small: At Pont-Aven, discover the total tranquillity of the tree houses of La Carri'air.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Up above an old stone quarry

paragraphs.text:
On the hills of Pont-Aven is a former quarry. It feels remote with its steep cliffs giving way to a moor that eventually becomes wooded. Here, near trembling mountain peaks, you will find three cabins designed like lodges, called Carri'air. Completely independent, these charming retreats are extremely comfortable and private.

The first, for families, is full of childhood reminiscences, decorated with antiques and vibrant colours. Higher up, the second is popular with lovebirds. This romantic getaway, chic, rustic, and immaculately decorated, features a bath with a view. The third takes you a further 10-metre closer to the skies. On its large terrace, you will enjoy a vantage point over the surroundings. Large picture windows also allow for unobstructed views during the whole stay.

Below the cabins are summer kitchens, sheltered and open, with a patio. And this is an unusual detail: breakfasts are served on the cabin terraces via a pulley. Your only visitor will be the occasional fox or deer crossing the quarry.

La Carri'air
19 rue Sainte-Marguerite
29930 Pont-Aven

+33 (0)6 12 37 28 90

https://lacarriair.com/

Rooms: from 119 EUR

content.title: Bénodet and its stunning coastal corniche

introduction.small: In Cornouaille, facing the ocean and the Glénan archipelago, Bénodet becomes a lively resort in summer.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bénodet and its stunning coastal corniche

paragraphs.text:
Bénodet, the seaside extension of Quimper just a few kilometres from the old city, is a gem set on the coast and bordered by the Odet, reputed to be the most beautiful river in France. With its chic atmosphere and unspoiled natural landscapes, Bénodet is often compared to Cannes. Its marina and four white sand beaches, languidly facing the enchanting islands of the archipelago Glénan, give it a postcard setting, replete with a dazzling display of beautiful sailboats.

Perfect for a short getaway, Bénodet is never more engaging than on its corniche road. Towards the estuary, just before the Phare du Coq lighthouse, sea bathing properties dating from the 19th century seem to defy time. Beyond are the pine trees of the Grande Plage and the rocky tip of Saint-Gilles. The casino, the elegant hotels, and the spa draw tourists, and the nights are always lively.

Bénodet Tourist Office
29 avenue de la Mer
29950 Bénodet

+33 (0)2 98 57 00 14

https://www.benodet-tourism.co.uk/

content.title: Bucolic chic at Domaine de Méros

introduction.small: At Plonévez-du-Faou, stay at the ancient Domaine de Méros and explore Brittany's hinterland.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bucolic chic at Domaine de Méros

paragraphs.text:
High above the Aulne, with a beautiful panoramic view of the Black Mountains, the Domaine de Méros and its 15th-century mansion exude the rustic atmosphere of green meadows, woods, and groves. Near the top of the mountain are nine intimate and cosy spa huts where one is invited to commune with nature. Combining luxury with a 360° view, a stove, and a Jacuzzi, these hilltop houses are unusual accommodations.

Guests who suffer from vertigo may prefer a bohemian house-on-wheels in the countryside, or the charm of a stone-walled suite in one of the manor's ancient outbuildings. The Domaine de Méros beckons you to come and explore its various riches. Near the English-style garden, there are horses and ponies: go for a ride through the well-marked forest trails.

Domaine de Méros
Lieu-dit Méros
29530 Plonévez-du-Faou

+33 (0)6 81 02 63 33

https://www.domainedemeros.com/

Cabin: from 150 EUR

content.title: Belle-Île-en-Mer and l'Île-aux-Moines: island pearls

introduction.small: One offshore and one within the Gulf of Morbihan, these two islands rival each other in beauty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Belle-Île-en-Mer and l'Île-aux-Moines: island pearls

paragraphs.text:
Belle-Île, the largest of the Breton islands, is an idyllic place off Quiberon, alternating jagged cliffs and some 50 tranquil beaches, including Bordardoué and Les Grands Sables. Its main ports, Le Palais and Sauzon, with their lively patios and market, are especially charming. This island pearl leaves no one indifferent, including Claude Monet, who painted here, and Sarah Bernhardt, whose property, set on the edge the Pointe des Poulains, is open to the public.

In the Gulf of Morbihan, the Île-aux-Moines is the gateway to 42 islands scattered over an inland sea. Its authentic fishermen's houses, pretty Bois d'Amour, and valleys covered in heather benefit from a mild climate all year. You can rent bikes at the dock in Port-Blanc, which connects Île-aux-Moines year-round to the mainland. This is by far the best way to discover its picturesque nooks and crannies at your own pace, wind in your hair and in complete freedom.

Belle-île-en-Mer tourist office
Quai Bonnelle
56360 Le Palais
+33 (0)2 97 31 81 93
https://www.belleileenmer.co.uk/

Île-aux-Moines tourist office
Rue Benoni Praud
56780 Île-aux-Moines
+33 (0)2 97 26 32 45
https://www.golfedumorbihan.bzh/

content.title: A traditional galette at Roi Gradlon

introduction.small: A gourmet getaway in one of the most popular traditional creperies in Brest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A traditional galette at Roi Gradlon

paragraphs.text:
Visitors should make it a point to visit this creperie located in the very centre of Brest, on a street parallel to the Rue de Siam. This local landmark eatery is named after one of the most famous kings of Armor, the former name of the land now known as Brittany. The name sets the tone: Roi Gradlon is a traditional creperie whose authenticity is in the details: wood panelling, subdued lighting, and small tables with white tablecloths. Buckwheat or wheat crepes, sweet or savoury, are made as soon as you order, using quality ingredients. Choose from a long list on the menu or customise your very own. The service is friendly and familial. A total success, for which it is strongly recommended to book ahead. There is a takeaway service, too.

La Crêperie du Roi Gradlon
19 rue Fautras
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 80 17 28

https://www.facebook.com/La-creperie-du-Roi-GRADLON-74070607511/

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: 100% nature at Brittany's Château de Sable

introduction.small: Less than 30 kilometres from Brest on the enchanting Iroise coastline, Château de Sable allows you to be one with nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 100% nature at Brittany's Château de Sable

paragraphs.text:
The eco-chic Château de Sable hotel ("sandcastle") is in Porspoder, a small coastal town of picturesque charm. On the edge of Europe facing the Saint-Laurent peninsula, this four-star hotel cultivates a close relationship with unspoilt nature. Nestled behind large windows overlooking the sea or gardens, rooms and suites are draped in noble and natural materials in a palette of soft colours.

Energy-saving devices, solar panels, and eco-friendly household products provide necessary comfort without neglecting the planet. This commitment is guaranteed by the 'Eco-hotel' label, which extends to the gourmet restaurant, where one finds seasonal vegetables and herbs from the organic garden at the Château de Kergroadez in Brélès. Chef Anthony Hardy gives pride of place to local products with a creative and fresh cuisine. Energising spa, marine and Ayurvedic treatments are nice extras.

Le Château de Sable
38 rue de l'Europe
29840 Porspoder

+33 (0)2 29 00 31 32

https://www.lechateaudesablehotel.fr

Rooms: from 88 EUR

content.title: Brest: along the docks

introduction.small: Old sailors, authentic bars, good seafood, and a choreographed ballet of boats: a visit to the docks of Brest is essential.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brest: along the docks

paragraphs.text:
It is difficult to forget that Brest is a working port city, especially along the lively banks of its commercial port, which give the city its unique character. Stroll past the shipyards and the legendary schooner La Recouvrance on the Quai du Commandant Malbert. The Quai de la Douane is home to the city's criée (fish auction) and many of its best restaurants, such as the famous Crabe Marteau.

Bars and restaurants also line the Quai Tabarly, facing the Château Marina. Brest's oldest building, the castle overlooks the city and is now a maritime museum. Don't forget to take in the magnificent views from the Pont Albert Louppe, the spectacular pedestrian and bicycle bridge over the Iroise.

Port de commerce
Quai de la Douane
29200 Brest

https://www.brest-metropole-tourisme.fr/

content.title: Le Crabe Marteau, by the harbour

introduction.small: Le Crabe Marteau is the best crab restaurant in Brest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Crabe Marteau, by the harbour

paragraphs.text:
Le Crabe Marteau is in a 19th-century building, one of the oldest in Brest's trading port. It is also one of the most popular places in the Ponant Cité. In the no-nonsense style of typical port eateries, it has solid wood tables and construction site buckets for table bins, and is generally rustic, friendly, and efficient. The refined dishware may be lacking, but diners are brought much-needed paraphernalia-wooden board, hammer, and bib-before their meals arrive.

And now, à l'attaque! Richly flavourful fresh crabs are served with a nice array of homemade sauces and organic Guipavas potatoes. For starters, you could try the crispy crab, then a hot-and-cold crab or artichokes and crab… You guessed it alright, crab is definitely the signature dish here, for your enjoyment. Depending on the day's catch, fish and seafood dominate the rest of the menu. And, in another sign of success, alongside others restaurants in Paris, Lorient and Bordeaux, Le Crabe Marteau has now recently opened a new one in Nantes.

Le Crabe Marteau
8 quai de la Douane
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 33 38 57

www.crabemarteau.fr

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: L'Agapa at Perros-Guirec: an absolute must in Brittany

introduction.small: On the spectacular Pink Granite Coast, the five-star L'Agapa is Breton luxury at its best.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Agapa at Perros-Guirec: an absolute must in Brittany

paragraphs.text:
The only five-star hotel in the Cotes d'Armor is in Perros-Guirec, on the stunning Pink Granite Coast looking out over the Sept-Îles Archipelago. Picture sea spray, white sand, emerald waters, and white gannets circling above. L'Agapa has elegantly revamped its 1930s heritage into a very contemporary space. The hotel rooms, suites, and surrounding villas exude understated luxury, refinement, and impeccable design, down to the smallest details.

Beyond the windows, the sea is never far away. Le Bélouga, the hotel's luminous gourmet restaurant, brings together a gorgeous view of the archipelago and an inventive cuisine of sublime Breton classics, like chitterling sausage from Guémené, oysters, and kouign-amann. L'Agapa also has a 400-square-metre Nuxe spa, featuring treatments like a Greek bath (with pink clay). It also has a swimming pool and outdoor terrace. A unique experience highlighted by perfect service, this is luxury in the breath-taking setting of the Bay of Trestraou (which means 'lower beach' in Breton).

L'Agapa
12 rue des Bons Enfants
22700 Perros-Guirec

+33 (0)2 96 49 01 10

https://www.lagapa.com/en/

Rooms: from 88 EUR (excluding breakfast)

content.title: La Butte: a contemporary house

introduction.small: With its seaside landscape, La Butte is a contemporary, Zen-like hotel that boasts a Michelin-starred restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Butte: a contemporary house

paragraphs.text:
Between Brest and Roscoff, the dunes and the ocean in the Bay of Goulven constitute La Butte's stunning backdrop. This hotel is one of the gems of Finistère. Wide open to the sea, the 33 rooms of La Butte showcase design. Radically minimalist, the mineral tones, Zen curves, touches of rawness, natural fabrics, and tree-trunks painted pristine white confer bright, warm elegance, very much like the hotel's attentive service.

The highlight of La Butte is the star restaurant with a view. The chef, Nicolas Conraux, awakens taste buds with sublime local produce and Breton cuisine. The hotel also has the Thémaé spa, with four treatment rooms for true wellness and relaxation. This is the spirit of Brittany, chicness and style included.

Logis Hôtel Spa La Butte
12 rue de la Mer
29260 Plouider

+33 (0)2 98 25 40 54

https://labutte.fr/home/

Rooms: from 86 EUR

content.title: Hotel Vauban: a little Brest melody

introduction.small: A hangout for rebellious musicians, Hotel Vauban cultivates the simplicity of a family-run hotel enlivened by rock 'n' roll escapades and an unspoilt singularity. A place full of character.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Vauban: a little Brest melody

paragraphs.text:
Brest's own 'Chelsea Hotel' is the Vauban. This spacious building from the 1950s, located in Ponant Cité, has welcomed the likes of Mistinguett, Charles Trenet, and Tino Rossi. Since 1962, there has been a concert hall in the basement-it is considered a historical monument of Brest musical life.

Today, musicians like Yann Tiersen and Herman Dune come here. It is not unusual to bump into Stephan Eicher or Miossec while padding through the hallways past the cosy retro brasserie. Musicians often stay in any of the 51 rooms in this deliciously old-fashioned hotel with its patina of years past. The hotel has retained its soul over multiple renovation works. Ask for Room 206. Done up in tartan in homage to Jane Birkin, it is a true replica of the 1950s.

Hôtel Vauban
17 avenue Georges Clemenceau
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 46 06 88

https://www.hotelvauban.fr

Rooms: from 63 EUR

content.title: Les Cintrés: a stylish restaurant-bar

introduction.small: Looking out at the Vivier peninsula, Les Cintrés is a bohemian and fun bar, ideal for sunny days.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Cintrés: a stylish restaurant-bar

paragraphs.text:
At the rear of the Les Cintrés boutique in Landunvez, where you can find items like local organic Route Mandarine soaps, is a cheerful bar-restaurant. The large open-plan room is imaginative and colourful, and furnished in an industrial and vintage style. Retro cinema seats sit alongside a blackboard, giant metal letters, and 1960s chairs.

The collection of clothes-hangers of all kinds are a signature part of Les Cintrés' decor. They hold pride of place in this pleasant, relaxed space. In summer, head for the outside: terrace and garden are sheltered from the wind and are perfect for a game of pétanque, billiards, or Breton boules. This friendly, affordable place with live music on certain evenings serves gourmet food and inventive cocktails, like a basil mojito accompanied with hummus, or a tapenade with anchovies.

Les Cintrés
25 route de Rochard
29840 Landunvez

+33 (0)2 98 01 45 45

www.lescintres.com

Menu: around 15 EUR

content.title: Les Vents de la Mer and its Michelin-starred chef

introduction.small: Les Vents de la Mer at Port Louis is a seaside and gastronomic getaway under the auspices of Patrice Gahinet, just one of the chefs to bring Brittany gastronomic acclaim.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Vents de la Mer and its Michelin-starred chef

paragraphs.text:
A few miles from Lorient, in the Gulf of Morbihan, Port Louis is a fortress town that has retained its picturesque charm. Les Vents de la Mer has everything to make you want to stay as long as possible. The family of Patrice Gahinet, head of the adjoining Michelin-starred restaurant Avel Vor, has extended his art of hospitality to the three pristine, sober-chic cottages.

Bathed in light, the cottages are wide open to the garden or the sea, and are full of seaside serenity. From the private terraces of two of them, Port Locmalo can be admired at leisure. And the evening brings Gahinet's cuisine for gourmet-loving guests. Behind the restaurant's glass wall, the sun sinks into a glowing sea as fish and seafood dishes parade from the kitchen, masterpieces of the inventive cuisine that first earned Gahinet his Michelin star in 2007.

Les Vents de la Mer - Avel Vor
25 route de Locmalo
56290 Port-Louis

+33 (0)2 97 82 47 59

www.restaurant-avel-vor.com/en/

Rooms: from 120 EUR

content.title: Le Jardin Gourmand: Lorient's version of organic

introduction.small: In two decades, the popularity of Breton chef Nathalie Beauvais is still going strong. Le Jardin Gourmand, her organic restaurant in Lorient, is a showcase.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Jardin Gourmand: Lorient's version of organic

paragraphs.text:
'The little fairy chef of Morbihan' is what Joël Robuchon used to call Nathalie Beauvais. This energetic woman is one of the high priestesses of Breton cuisine. You can sense her love for Breton food in her books, blog, and cooking classes... And, obviously, at her restaurant in Lorient. Le Jardin Gourmand is in a traditional stone house with a beautiful patio and garden. Its sober, modern decor has been the perfect backdrop for good, local, and organic food for 25 years. Beauvais' commitment has earned her restaurant the environmental seal of approval. She reinvents her flavourful market cuisine every day according to the season and what's available at the market. But she does have signature dishes, like oysters from the Bay of Quiberon and Guémené-sur-Scorff andouille (smoked pork sausage) on toast or scallops cooked in buckwheat papillote and served with prawn cream in kari Gosse (delightful Breton curry). End the meal on a subtle note with an orange-infused chocolate fondant served with citrus fruits and orange sorbet.

Le Jardin Gourmand
46 rue Jules Simon
56100 Lorient

+33 (0)2 97 64 17 24

https://www.tropmad.com/

Menu: around 46 EUR

content.title: Le Sistrot: Brittany's first cider bar

introduction.small: Le Sistrot in Quimper is faithful to Breton terroir, and introduces guests to cidrology.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Sistrot: Brittany's first cider bar

paragraphs.text:
Brittany's first cider bar was founded by two Breton brothers, passionate about cuisine and their land, and, for a time, expatriates in Montreal. When they returned home, they decided to start a restaurant-bar dedicated to the most Breton of all beverages, cider. And thus, overlooking the water on Boulevard Amiral de Kerguélen in Quimper, was born Le Sistrot, contraction of the words sistr (Breton for cider) and bistrot. Set up with the bar in focus, where a wide selection of craft and farm ciders are displayed. There are classic and more original ciders, pear cider, mead, and lambic. The brothers also import the fire and ice ciders from the Eastern Townships of Quebec. To accompany these beautiful beverages, the establishment offers market cuisine for lunch and a small selection of dishes for dinner.

Le Sistrot
53 boulevard Amiral de Kerguélen
29000 Quimper

+33 (0)2 98 10 73 46

www.lesistrot.com

Menu: around 22 EUR

content.title: Hinoki: the art of sushi

introduction.small: Hinoki's acclaimed sushi showcases Finistère's local seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hinoki: the art of sushi

paragraphs.text:
In the very select club of Japanese-French restaurants that perpetuate the excellent art of sushi, Hinoki is a standard-bearer. This small restaurant with minimalist decor is nestled in a little alley in the centre of Brest. It is owned by chef Xavier Pensec and his Japanese wife, who has retained from her native Tokyo the precision of large sushiyas.

Xavier Pensec selects the best fish in Finistère-bream, bass, mackerel, skipjack tuna and sardines-which he marries with a cooked and seasoned nigiri rice that leaves nothing to chance. Hinoki does not serve bluefin tuna out of respect for the environment. At the counter, guests watch the choreographed rhythm of the Japanese knife as it produces a range of sushi, maki, and chirashi. Though Pensec is Breton, he is a 'sushi craftsman' in the tradition of the Japanese masters. You may therefore opt for the “Chirashi matsu”, the large rice bowl being covered with an assortment of fish of the day, served with miso soup. Reservations are strongly recommended at least 24 hours in advance.

Hinoki
6 rue des 11 Martyrs
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 43 23 68

https://www.facebook.com/www.sushinoki.fr

Menus: from 68 EUR

content.title: Galerie de Ker-Iliz in Perros-Guirec: 100% Brittany

introduction.small: One of the most iconic stores in Perros-Guirec, with a nice selection of gift items and sweets from the region.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Galerie de Ker-Iliz in Perros-Guirec: 100% Brittany

paragraphs.text:
In a house designed by James Bouille, the founder of neo-Breton architecture, the Galerie de Ker-Iliz is an institution in Perros-Guirec. An ironmonger in the 1950s, it has evolved over three family generations into a gallery dedicated to Brittany. Gifts, souvenirs, crafts, but also ready-to-wear and decorative items fill the shelves of this huge, centrally located shop.

Traditional Breton biscuits sit next to a nice selection of clothing items by Petit Bateau, along with postcards, Celtic jewellery, a space dedicated to the famous Henriot brand of Quimper porcelain, Breton bowls, a record section, books, and Nominoë organic cosmetics. Whether something classic, trendy, or unusual, it is hard not to find something at Galerie de Ker-Iliz worth slipping into your luggage before going back home.

Galerie de Ker-Iliz
6 rue du Général de Gaulle
22700 Perros-Guirec

+33 (0)2 96 91 00 96

https://www.facebook.com/Galerie-De-Ker-Iliz-439471616200287/

content.title: Hostellerie de la Pointe Saint-Mathieu: facing the elements

introduction.small: Far from the Ponant Cité, the timeless chic of the Hostellerie de la Pointe Saint-Mathieu, in stark contrast with the untamed nature that surrounds it, is sure to please.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hostellerie de la Pointe Saint-Mathieu: facing the elements

paragraphs.text:
Twenty kilometres west of Brest at Plougonvelin, the rocks of Pointe Saint-Mathieu seem to tumble into a windswept ocean. This exceptional setting, an ode to wild, rough, and indomitable Finistère, is where the Hostellerie de la Pointe Saint-Mathieu has set up residence.

Opposite the lighthouse and the abbey, the 33 rooms of this four-star 'Relais du Silence' look out to the dramatic ocean. You feel like you are among the rolling waves in these rooms, designed like chic, cocoon-like ship's cabins with wood panelling and portholes, and decorated in shades of blue. Some rooms include balconies to better contemplate the horizon. With a minimalist, bright Carita spa and a gourmet restaurant in a 14th-century stone building, the Hostellerie de la Pointe Saint-Mathieu is a destination in itself, though there are many places to visit nearby, beginning with Ouessant. It exudes a quiet charm, ideal for a great seaside escape.

Hostellerie de la Pointe Saint-Mathieu
7 place Saint-Tanguy
29217 Plougonvelin

+33 (0)2 98 89 00 19

www.pointe-saint-mathieu.com/en/

Rooms: from 84 EUR

content.title: Full sail to the Glénan archipelago

introduction.small: With its white sandy beaches lapped by translucent water, the Glénan archipelago off Concarneau feels like it's in the South Seas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Full sail to the Glénan archipelago

paragraphs.text:
In the Glénan archipelago (which emblem is the narcissus flower), around the main, floral-rich island of Saint-Nicolas, are dozens of small islets and rocky outcrops-island paradises surrounded by simple turquoise waters. Protected from pollution and endowed with an ecosystem of incredible wealth, they provide splendid opportunities for diving: if you're lucky, you'll come face to face with a harmless basking shark. But for visiting the “Breton Caribbean” by sea, sailing is undeniably the best option, especially as the Glénans sailing school is one of the largest in Europe. For a sailing course, a weekend, or a simple outing, you can choose from a wide fleet of catamarans, cruising boats, sea kayaks, windsurf boards or dinghies to take on the crystal-clear waters of this inland sea! Don't pass up a chance to dine at Les Viviers Glénan, the restaurant of the Castric family, owners of the famous fish tanks of Saint-Nicolas, which serves a fabulous blue Breton lobster.

Les Glénans
Place Philippe Vianney
29900 Concarneau
+33 (0)1 53 92 86 00
https://www.glenans.asso.fr/

Les Viviers des Glénan
Île Saint-Nicolas
29170 Fouesnant
+33 (0)2 98 50 68 90
https://restaurantlesviviers.wixsite.com/castric

content.title: From Lorient to the Rhuys Peninsula: Southern Brittany

introduction.small: The coast of southern Brittany is richly endowed with inviting port towns and beaches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: From Lorient to the Rhuys Peninsula: Southern Brittany

paragraphs.text:
From Lorient, a lively 17th-century port city marked by the conquest of India, to the Rhuys Peninsula, dotted with inviting beaches, salt marshes, and oyster beds, and infused with the spirit of the Dukes of Brittany-as evidenced majestically by the Château de Suscinio – the coast surrounding the Gulf of Morbihan is full of remarkable sites and landscapes.

Highlights include Port-Louis and its citadel, Rochefort-en-Terre, with its timeless back streets prized by artisans; the stepped streets of La Roche-Bernard built right into the rock slope; and Vannes, the capital, with its wood-framed houses. Another is the spectacular Quiberon Peninsula, with its kilometres of sandy beaches, interspersed with rocks and cliffs lapped by rolling waves, making it one of the best surf spots in Brittany. And then of course there's Etel, Carnac, and the myriad of magical islands: Groix, Belle Île, Gavrinis, Île-aux-Moines, Houat, and Hoëdic...

www.morbihan-tourism.co.uk/

content.title: Galerie Kuuutch: a non-profit gallery for Breton art and design

introduction.small: Galerie Kuuutch invites passers-by to plunge into the creative effervescence of Brittany.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Galerie Kuuutch: a non-profit gallery for Breton art and design

paragraphs.text:
Galerie Kuuutch was started by two designers who wished to open a creative showcase for local talent in their graphic arts studio in the centre of Brest, close to Halles Saint Louis. The non-profit space is next to their office. Slate grey walls and slat panel modules serve as the setting for screen-printed posters, photographs, records, jewellery, decorative objects, ceramics, textiles designs, and illustrations, all by Breton artists. The emphasis is clearly placed on Brest.

This unique place also holds special events that bring together the city's artistic community: rummage sales, encounters, pop-ups, record swaps... you are guaranteed to find something interesting to take home in your luggage. Open Fridays 2:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. and Saturdays 10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.

Galerie Kuuutch (Les Établis)
17 rue Fautras
29200 Brest

https://www.facebook.com/Kuuutch-251633228338727/

content.title: Flavours of the sea at Madec

introduction.small: In summer, Prat-Ar-Coum is the best place in Madec territory to have oysters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Flavours of the sea at Madec

paragraphs.text:
Since 1898, the Madec family has ruled the oyster beds of Prat-Ar-Coum, making this corner of Brittany a benchmark for oyster lovers. It is possible to shop here, but there is also a small restaurant nestled in what was the home of the foreman. This is the place to try Prat-Ar-Coum oysters, lobsters, and crayfish directly from the banks of the Aber Benoît. In the wine cellar, you will find a large selection of reds, whites and rosés (from the Loire, Alsace, Bourgogne, Provence and Champagne regions) to pair with your selection.

The heated terrace overlooks the ponds and oyster beds. This Finistère view is especially stunning when the sun sets. Inside, the ambience is laid back and maritime, with teak furniture and wood siding. The restaurant is seasonal (from 1 July to 31 August only) and booking is highly recommended.

Restaurant Prat-Ar-Coum
Lieu-dit Prat Ar Coum
29870 Lannilis

+33 (0)2 98 04 00 12

https://www.prat-ar-coum.fr/fr/le-restaurant

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: Fonds Leclerc: a museum in a renovated supermarket

introduction.small: A former E. Leclerc supermarket next to a listed monastery, this exceptional site houses the centre for contemporary art of the Breton-born supermarket magnate Édouard Leclerc.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fonds Leclerc: a museum in a renovated supermarket

paragraphs.text:
In 2012, the year of his death, Édouard Leclerc, the founder of the E. Leclerc supermarket chain, along with his wife Hélène, opened a vast space dedicated to contemporary art in the Domaine des Capucins in his hometown of Landerneau, roughly 20 km from Brest. Installed inside the former E. Leclerc supermarket next to a 17th-century convent and in the large courtyard and chapel, the Fonds Hélène & Édouard Leclerc Pour La Culture contains some 1,200 sqm of exhibition space.

Each year, two or three major exhibitions introduce the public to some of the most iconic artists of our time. Since opening in 2012, artists such as Gérard Fromanger, Yann Kersalé, Joan Miró, Jean Dubuffet, Jacques Monory, and Alberto Giacometti have been shown inside the walls of the giant cultural centre. A collection of European sacred art, dating from the 14th to the 18th century, is on display in the adjacent chapel.

Fonds Hélène & Édouard Leclerc pour la Culture
71 rue de la Fontaine Blanche
29800 Landerneau

+33 (0)2 29 62 47 78

https://www.fonds-culturel-leclerc.fr

content.title: Monts d'Arrée: for glorious nature walks

introduction.small: Outdoor enthusiasts, lace up your hiking boots for a walking trip in fascinating Monts d'Arrée—unless you prefer to do it on horseback or mountain bike.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Monts d'Arrée: for glorious nature walks

paragraphs.text:
You have to leave the coast to reach Monts d'Arrée, which is deep in the heart of Brittany's mysterious pays breizh countryside. This is a place of legend: hilly and mountainous landscapes of peaks, rocks, heather, and gorse, and absolute silence, with no trace of human presence other than the few steeples rising from the countryside, some small chapels, and isolated parish enclosures.

Hiking is the best way to reach the top of the Roc'h Ruz, the highest peak of the massif in the Parc Naturel Régional d'Armorique, which cleaves Finistère in two. The GR 380 takes you on a loop, past panoramas that border on the surreal. But this piece of preserved Brittany also lends itself well to horseback riding or mountain biking. In any case, the change of scenery and athletic thrills are guaranteed!

Monts d'Arrée
29410 Plounéour-Ménez

+33 (0)2 98 68 88 40

https://www.montsdarreetourisme.bzh/

content.title: Océanopolis: a unique marine centre in Europe

introduction.small: Close to the Atlantic, Océanopolis provides an introduction to 1,000 marine species from around the world. More than an aquarium, this is one of the iconic sights of Brest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Océanopolis: a unique marine centre in Europe

paragraphs.text:
The giant Océanopolis marine centre in Brest, near the Moulin Blanc marina, is the only one of its kind in Europe. Opened in 1990, it remains one of the most visited attractions in Brittany. With its 77 aquariums and pools, three pavilions (tropical, temperate, and polar) and about a thousand various species, it offers visitors a fascinating plunge into the maritime world.

The display designs are playful and innovative, interweaving both science and spectacle in the space's 9,000 square metres. The array of marine life-seals, sharks, rays, groupers, neon tetra, and deep-sea shrimp, to name a few examples-attracts young and old alike. Don't miss the polar bear habitat, the sea elephant model, the panoramic movie 49° South: Southern Nature, the impressive coral reef, or the pedagogical marine laboratory. A must visit, just a few steps from the ocean, which will open your eyes to the mysteries of the deep.

Océanopolis
Port de Plaisance du Moulin Blanc
29200 Brest

+33 (0)2 98 34 40 40

https://www.oceanopolis.com/en/welcome

content.title: Miramar La Cigale: a seaside ode to wellness

introduction.small: The pearl of Breton thalassotherapy, Miramar La Cigale is an exceptional place to experience all the benefits of Brittany.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Miramar La Cigale: a seaside ode to wellness

paragraphs.text:
Resembling an immaculate ship securely moored to the Rhuys peninsula in the Morbihan, the 5-star Miramar La Cigale is one of the most beautiful thalassotherapy establishments in Brittany.

In the 113 plush rooms and suites with pure lines, an aquatic touch of green enhances the beige and white palette, an extension of the views from the large windows looking out onto Fogeo beach. Another place to look at the view is from the terraces, swept by gentle sea breezes.
Apart from the restaurant, bar, and seawater pool is the top-flight thalassotherapy centre, bringing the benefits of the marine world to our health and wellness. True to its reputation, Miramar La Cigale is the ideal home base for discerning travellers who want to explore Brittany while staying in the comfort, care, and restfulness of a refined hotel.

Miramar La Cigale Hotel Thalasso & Spa
Port du Crouesty
Route du Petit Mont
56640 Arzon

+33 (0)2 97 53 49 13

https://www.miramar-lacigale.com/en/

Rooms: from 165 EUR

content.title: MeatCouture: a delicatessen for couture carnivores

introduction.small: Have lunch in this upscale butcher shop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MeatCouture: a delicatessen for couture carnivores

paragraphs.text:
Formerly the top apprentice butcher in Brittany, Andriy Maximov is not just any meat merchant. Having worked at Hugo Desnoyer, Yves-Marie Le Bourdonnec and Dickson's Farmstand Meats in New York, he has imported Dickson's brick walls and deli ambience to MeatCouture, a very exclusive butcher shop that features a handpicked selection of fine cuts.

Meat hanging in cold lockers is cut to order at the central butcher's block. At lunchtime, it serves as a lunch counter. Or one can pull up a stool and eat while gazing through the wall-sized front window at the Recouvrance Bridge. The menu features delicious corned beef, ravioli stuffed with lamb from Lozère, a leg of lamb in homemade basil pesto and marinated peppers, sirloin steak with rosemary, shoulder of lamb in snail butter and Elena Burgers – named after Andriy's wife. Also, try the mouth-watering T-Bone steak and ham hock, aged by the master and cooked to order. MeatCouture also serves breakfasts and, twice a month, gourmet dinners. A one-of-a-kind address in Brest!

MeatCouture
6 rue de la Porte
29200 Brest

+33 (0)9 81 00 62 03

https://meatcouture.com/

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: Discover historic Brest

introduction.small: In the Recouvrance district, quaint vestiges spared by the bombings of World War II provide a charming glimpse of the Brest of old.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover historic Brest

paragraphs.text:
Strategically placed facing the Atlantic, Brest has often found itself at the centre of history, from the Romans to Du Guesclin, Richelieu, and Vauban. Yet few traces of this turbulent past remain in the city, which was destroyed by bombing in the Second World War. To visit its historic soul, so important to the people of Brest, head to the Recouvrance district. Perched on a block of granite, the Tanguy Tower, with its small museum, is among its most iconic remains.

Further south, the Jardin des Explorateurs pays homage to some of the world's most important maritime expeditions. Steps away is the Maison de la Fontaine, one of the oldest houses in the city, dating from the 17th century. But to truly find the atmosphere of old Brest, push north to the picturesque rue Saint-Malo, with its ancient washhouse (lavoir), paving stones, and well-preserved houses.

Musée de la tour Tanguy (Tanguy Tower)
Square Pierre Péron
29200 Brest
+33 (0)2 98 00 80 80
https://www.brest.fr/culture/les-equipements-culturels/la-tour-tanguy-une-sentinelle-sur-la-penfeld-2126.html
